messages.text: Hi, all. I wish to contribute to the Julia VSCode Extension for GSoC 2021. I have been working with TypeScript development since sophomore year. And during last fall, I worked on Julia as an MLH Fellowship student. I authored a package <https://github.com/JuliaGeo/GADM.jl|JuliaGeo/GADM.jl> under the mentorship of <@UA3UH56HL>, contributed several PRs to other Julia projects, and used the extension extensively. Going through the idealist, this one sounds the most aligned to my interests. <@U68UUUFPS> I would be glad if you can give some pointers on where to start with this idea: <https://julialang.org/jsoc/gsoc/vscode/#vs_code_extension>

elements.text: Hi, all. I wish to contribute to the Julia VSCode Extension for GSoC 2021. I have been working with TypeScript development since sophomore year. And during last fall, I worked on Julia as an MLH Fellowship student. I authored a package
JuliaGeo/GADM.jl
under the mentorship of
, contributed several PRs to other Julia projects, and used the extension extensively. Going through the idealist, this one sounds the most aligned to my interests.
I would be glad if you can give some pointers on where to start with this idea:

messages.text: Hey folks, I was wondering if there is a good `.gitignore` file creator in vscode for julia files? Like I was looking through the vscode extensions and there are a bunch for creating `.gitignore` files, but i was not sure if there were any extensions that folks who work with Julia use? For example, I have a bunch of weave files and I don't want the intermediate artifacts saved, but only the final html and jmd files.

elements.text: Hey folks, I was wondering if there is a good
.gitignore
file creator in vscode for julia files? Like I was looking through the vscode extensions and there are a bunch for creating
.gitignore

files, but i was not sure if there were any extensions that folks who work with Julia use? For example, I have a bunch of weave files and I don't want the intermediate artifacts saved, but only the final html and jmd files.

, but yes, would be great to add that to the real docs

messages.text: Yeah mostly all the projects have it in their README.md or CONTRIBUTING.md. I think since our readme is pretty short we can add it there for now.

elements.text: Yeah mostly all the projects have it in their README.md or CONTRIBUTING.md. I think since our readme is pretty short we can add it there for now.

messages.text: <https://github.com/julia-vscode/julia-vscode/issues/2079>

Actually, I think it would be better to have these in a CONTRIBUTING.md. The README.md also doubles as the material that is shown in the marketplace, and I think generally it is better if that a) is short and b) really primarily targets end users.

elements.text: Actually, I think it would be better to have these in a CONTRIBUTING.md. The README.md also doubles as the material that is shown in the marketplace, and I think generally it is better if that a) is short and b) really primarily targets end users.

messages.text:
Hey,
I’m having some trouble with dependencies, specifically DifferentialEquations. It seems to work fine in terminal so I think it might be a vscode issue.
When I get a REPL open in vs code and do `using DifferentialEquations` I get an error (I’ll post the stacktrace in comments) with the top-line being:
`julia> using DifferentialEquations`
`[ Info: Precompiling DifferentialEquations [0c46a032-eb83-5123-abaf-570d42b7fbaa]`
`ERROR: LoadError: LoadError: ArgumentError: Package CompilerSupportLibraries_jll [e66e0078-7015-5450-92f7-15fbd957f2ae] is required but does not seem to be installed:`
 `- Run `Pkg.instantiate()` to install all recorded dependencies.`

If i do ] instantaite in the REPL, I then get:
`ERROR: ArgumentError: Unsupported architecture 'aarch64' for macOS`

Any ideas what’s going wrong and how to fix?

elements.text:
Hey,
I’m having some trouble with dependencies, specifically DifferentialEquations. It seems to work fine in terminal so I think it might be a vscode issue.
When I get a REPL open in vs code and do
using DifferentialEquations
I get an error (I’ll post the stacktrace in comments) with the top-line being:
julia> using DifferentialEquations
[ Info: Precompiling DifferentialEquations [0c46a032-eb83-5123-abaf-570d42b7fbaa]
ERROR: LoadError: LoadError: ArgumentError: Package CompilerSupportLibraries_jll [e66e0078-7015-5450-92f7-15fbd957f2ae] is required but does not seem to be installed:
- Run `Pkg.instantiate()` to install all recorded dependencies.
If i do ] instantaite in the REPL, I then get:
ERROR: ArgumentError: Unsupported architecture 'aarch64' for macOS
Any ideas what’s going wrong and how to fix?

messages.text: Is there a way to limit how many julia processes the vscode plugin can start? I often need to `kill` 2-3 dozen julia process every week to reclaim memory. I usually have half a dozen vscode windows open, but only a couple Julia REPLs which is why I suspect it's vscode or the language server.

elements.text: Is there a way to limit how many julia processes the vscode plugin can start? I often need to
kill
2-3 dozen julia process every week to reclaim memory. I usually have half a dozen vscode windows open, but only a couple Julia REPLs which is why I suspect it's vscode or the language server.

messages.text: Every window starts one Julia process for the LS, and then maybe temporarily one process for the symbol server, but that should shut down once indexing is done. I don't think there is much we can do about the LS process... We are working on a redesign that will hopefully make the indexing step go away for the most part.

elements.text: Every window starts one Julia process for the LS, and then maybe temporarily one process for the symbol server, but that should shut down once indexing is done. I don't think there is much we can do about the LS process... We are working on a redesign that will hopefully make the indexing step go away for the most part.

messages.text: Dozens of processes sounds like a lot though. I recall some people were noticing an issue about the Jupyter notebook kernel on Discourse

elements.text: Dozens of processes sounds like a lot though. I recall some people were noticing an issue about the Jupyter notebook kernel on Discourse

messages.text: <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/stray-julia-processes/58270/6>

attachments.title: Stray Julia Processes
attachments.text: Did you shutdown the kernels before closing the browser window of the notebooks? If not, the kernels may still be running. If you use Jupyter notebooks, try jupyter notebook list to see the running kernels.

messages.text:
> There definitely was a bug where processes would be orphaned when VSCode was closed
That seems likely, I'm frequently opening and close windows for various repos and if there's a language server for each windows then that could pile up. I've tried updating a bunch of things to see if that fixes the problem.  I was mostly just wondering if there was a way to tell vscode to look for a centralized language server for all of my windows.

messages.text:
I’m not quite sure how I should be using vscode/julia. Basically what I want is to have two files, which are similar to two Jupyter notebooks in the sense that I want to execute some blocks of code at a time, and sometimes the whole file.
Running the whole file with Run: Start Without Debugging is not a good idea as it closes Julia when the file is done.
Ctrl+Enter kind of works, but it sent the code to the same REPL from the two files, which is not what I wanted.

elements.text:
I’m not quite sure how I should be using vscode/julia. Basically what I want is to have two files, which are similar to two Jupyter notebooks in the sense that I want to execute some blocks of code at a time, and sometimes the whole file.
Running the whole file with Run: Start Without Debugging is not a good idea as it closes Julia when the file is done.
Ctrl+Enter kind of works, but it sent the code to the same REPL from the two files, which is not what I wanted.

messages.text:
What I would ideally want is what I can get in RStudio with New File -> R Notebook, which gives me this:
```---
title: "R Notebook"
output: html_notebook
---

This is an [R Markdown](<http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>) Notebook. When you execute code within the notebook, the results appear beneath the code. 

Try executing this chunk by clicking the *Run* button within the chunk or by placing your cursor inside it and pressing *Cmd+Shift+Enter*. 

```{r}
plot(cars)
```

Add a new chunk by clicking the *Insert Chunk* button on the toolbar or by pressing *Cmd+Option+I*.

When you save the notebook, an HTML file containing the code and output will be saved alongside it (click the *Preview* button or press *Cmd+Shift+K* to preview the HTML file). 

The preview shows you a rendered HTML copy of the contents of the editor. Consequently, unlike *Knit*, *Preview* does not run any R code chunks. Instead, the output of the chunk when it was last run in the editor is displayed.```

elements.text: What I would ideally want is what I can get in RStudio with New File -> R Notebook, which gives me this:

---
title: "R Notebook"
output: html_notebook
---

This is an [R Markdown](

) Notebook. When you execute code within the notebook, the results appear beneath the code. 

Try executing this chunk by clicking the *Run* button within the chunk or by placing your cursor inside it and pressing *Cmd+Shift+Enter*. 

```{r}
plot(cars)
```

Add a new chunk by clicking the *Insert Chunk* button on the toolbar or by pressing *Cmd+Option+I*.

When you save the notebook, an HTML file containing the code and output will be saved alongside it (click the *Preview* button or press *Cmd+Shift+K* to preview the HTML file). 

The preview shows you a rendered HTML copy of the contents of the editor. Consequently, unlike *Knit*, *Preview* does not run any R code chunks. Instead, the output of the chunk when it was last run in the editor is displayed.

messages.text:
Wrapping the code in a module didn’t work as expected. Here’s the file (this is a homework):
```module ProbabilityDistributions

function bernoulli(p::Real)
	return rand() <= p
end

function geometric(p::Real)::Integer
	if p==0
		throw(ArgumentError("Function called with p == 0"))
	end
	t = 1
	while true
		if bernoulli(p)
			return t
		end
		t += 1
	end
end

end```
I put the cursor inside a function like bernoulli, I hit Alt-Enter, and I think the function is defined in module Main.
```julia> function bernoulli(p::Real)
        return rand() <= p
       end
bernoulli (generic function with 1 method)

julia> @which bernoulli(0.5)
bernoulli(p::Real) in Main at /Volumes/MyFiles/Learning/misc-tryout-2/hw6-probability-distributions.jl:3```
If I select all of the contents and hit Alt-Enter, it goes properly to the module, but that’s not exactly what I wanted.

elements.text: Wrapping the code in a module didn’t work as expected. Here’s the file (this is a homework):

module ProbabilityDistributions

function bernoulli(p::Real)
	return rand() <= p
end

function geometric(p::Real)::Integer
	if p==0
		throw(ArgumentError("Function called with p == 0"))
	end
	t = 1
	while true
		if bernoulli(p)
			return t
		end
		t += 1
	end
end

end
I put the cursor inside a function like bernoulli, I hit Alt-Enter, and I think the function is defined in module Main.

julia> function bernoulli(p::Real)
        return rand() <= p
       end
bernoulli (generic function with 1 method)

julia> @which bernoulli(0.5)
bernoulli(p::Real) in Main at /Volumes/MyFiles/Learning/misc-tryout-2/hw6-probability-distributions.jl:3
If I select all of the contents and hit Alt-Enter, it goes properly to the module, but that’s not exactly what I wanted.

messages.text:
I'm trying to be a bit more careful about the research code that I write, so I'm making a package for the first time.

Is there a configuration that I need to manually set so VSCode can find the function definitions? As in, so the docstrings show up along with the location in the code.
For instance, when editing the code in `test/` , VSCode seems to be unaware of the files in  `src/`, despite being able to run the tests correctly.

Edit: To give a little more information, the structure is roughly the following, where VSCode doesn't find the definition for `foobar()` when editing runtests.jl, despite being able to run the file with `SHIFT+ENTER` correctly

src/Foo.jl
```module Foo
include("Bar.jl")
end```
src/Bar.jl
```"""
    foobar()

This function does something
"""
function foobar()
    return 1
end```
test/runtests.jl
```using Foo, Test
...```

, despite being able to run the tests correctly.
